p.seg: This letter [I,e, the original version of 90-09-13] consists of three sheets. The sheet beginning with Es wurde wichtig is numbered 5 and so possibly belongs with the dated and signed sheet or another long letter with more than four pages. The sheet beginning with In Bezug auf Livistonia is not numbered and could go with any letter.
There are no marginal additions to any sheet with the exception of the signed and dated sheet which has a clear marginal insertion in the text.
You two will have to sort it out from the context of what is written as I've proofed all three sheets.
For the purpose of finding the sheets again in the files, the two undated sheets are with the signed and dated sheet.
I suspect the only way to sort out the Holtze mess would be to go to SA and look at the originals to match up folds in the sheets and so on and even then it might not be possible.

p.seg: In Bezug auf Livistona Leichhardtii möchte ich bemerken, dass solche von mir beschrieben wurde, als ich glaubte, dass R Brown seine L. humilis u. L. inermis beide von der Ostküste hatte; es ergab sich aber später, dass Beide von der Nordküste kamen, u es scheinten nur 2 Varietäten

Art zu sein. Keiner der Namen passt; denn die Blattstiele sind (glaube ich) immer dornig oder stachelig (ist dies so?) u der Stamm im Alter ist hoch. Am Besten wäre es die 2 unpassenden Namen zu unterdrücken und den von Livistona Leichhardtii gelten zu lassen.

Wie schade, dass Ihnen die Mittel so beschränkt sind, zumal in einer neuen Gegend, wo Ihre Versuchs-Culturen für tropische Plantagen den Weg bahnen sollen, u da Sie mit Begeisterung für Ihre Aufgabe schwärmen!
Hr Krichauff u Hr Basedow, die ja beide im Parliament sind, könnten wohl Ihre Lage verbessern.
Acacia vera ist identisch mit A. Arabica. Doch möchte ich gern gelegentlich Blätter u Früchte Ihrer dortigen Pflanze sehen, um die Richtigkeit des Namens zu ermitteln.
Von den zwei dortigen Bambus Arten fehlen noch immer die Blüthen u Samen. Freilich blühen diese Gewächse gewöhnlich nicht jedes Jahr, ja in manchen Fällen nur nach vielen Jahren.
Wenn es Ihnen nütz, will ich gern von Zeit zu Zeit einige £ senden, womit Sie etwaige Sammler bezahlen könnten, die von entlegneren Gegenden etwas bringen möchten.
Auf der Melville Insel kommt ein Cochlospermum vor, das von den beiden Arten Ihrer Nähe verschieden sein soll.
Es ist gut, dass Sie auch etwas von Port Essington erlangt haben.
Samen von A. Arabica werden sehr willkommen zur Vertheilung hier sein; für mehrere tropische Länder wären Samen

div.p:
Concerning Livistona leichhardtii
See also M to M. Holtze, 27 October 1883, no. 332, and M. Holtze to M, 16 March 1892 (in this edition as 92-03-16a). I want to remark that it was described by me when I believed that R. Brown had got both his L. humilis and his L. inermis from the east coast, but it was established later that both came from the north coast and seem to be just two varieties of one species. Neither of the names is suitable
humilis = of low growth, inermis = unarmed, lacking thorns. add reference.
because the petioles are (I believe) always thorny or spiny (is that the case?), and the trunk becomes tall with age. It would be best to suppress the two unsuitable names and to validate that of Livistona leichhardtii.

What a shame that your funds are so limited, all the more so in a new area where your experimental cultures are to pave the way for tropical plantations and you are filled with enthusiastic eagerness for your task!

Mr Krichauff and Mr Basedow who, as you know, are both in Parliament, could no doubt improve your situation.
other refs. to Krichauff &/or Basedow re assistance: 85.11.10, 88.05.04.
Acacia vera is identical with A. arabica. But when convenient I would like to see leaves and fruit of your local plant there to determine the accuracy of that name.

The flowers and seed of the two bamboo species from there are still lacking. It is true that these plants don't flower every year as a rule and in many cases only after many years.
An on-going quest!, see also 79.[11.09?], 80.04.04, 81.08.19, 82.05.21 (from Holtze), 86.12.12, 89.06.12, 90.05.16, 90.10.02. — I seem to recall that bambus flowers only once in [20? or was it even 100?] years and dies after flowering. Ask Neville.

If it is of help to you, I should be happy to send you a few £ from time to time to pay for likely collectors who might bring something from more remote regions.
See also 83.10.26 on the same subject.

A Cochlospermum is found on Melville Island that is supposed to differ from both the species from near you.
M had requested specimens of Cochlospermum from Melville Island in M to M. Holtze, 26 October 1883 and M to M. Holtze, 6 January 1884. M to M. Holtze1883, in this edition as 83-00-00l, no. 232, also includes a Cochlospermum, but does not mention Melville Island.

It is good that you have also obtained material from Port Essington.
An abandoned settlement on the Cobourg Peninsula, NT.

Seeds of Acacia arabica would be very welcome for distribution here.
See also M to M. Holtze, 7 February 1888 (in this edition as 88-02-07a); M to M. Holtze, 4 May 1888 (in this edition as 88-05-04b); and M to M. Holtze, 20 October 1888 (in this edition as 88-10-20a). Seeds of your eucalypts would be very desirable for several tropical countries.
